text: A repunit is a number like 11, 111, or 1111. It only has the digit 1 in it. It is a more specific type of repdigit. The term stands for repeated unit and was coined in 1966 by Albert H. Beiler in his book Recreations in the Theory of Numbers. A repunit prime is a repunit that is also a prime number. Primes that are repunits in base-2 are Mersenne primes. == Definition == The base-b repunits can be written as this where b is the base and n is the number that you are checking in whether or not it is a repunit: : R_n^{(b)}\equiv 1 + b + b^2 + \cdots + b^{n-1} = {b^n-1\over{b-1}}\qquad\mbox{for }|b|\ge2, n\ge1. This means that the number Rn(b) is made of of of n copies of the digit 1 in base-b representation. The first two repunits base-b for n = 1 and n = 2 are : R_1^{(b)}={b-1\over{b-1}}= 1 \qquad \text{and} \qquad R_2^{(b)}={b^2-1\over{b-1}}= b+1\qquad\text{for}\ |b|\ge2. The first of repunits in base-10 are with : 1, 11, 111, 1111, 11111, 111111, ... . Base-2 repunits are also Mersenne numbers Mn = 2n − 1\. They start with : 1, 3, 7, 15, 31, 63, 127, 255, 511, 1023, 2047, 4095, 8191, 16383, 32767, 65535, ... . == Factorization of decimal repunits == Prime factors that are are "new factors" that haven't been mentioned before. Basically, the prime factor divides Rn but does not divide Rk for all k < n.
